title: China Eximbank provides $160.2 million preferential buyer's credit loan for Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge (linked to #61205)
description: In June 2004, China Exim Bank and the Government Indonesia signed a memorandum of understanding regarding a loan for the  Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project. Then, on November 5, 2004, China Eximbank and the Government of Indonesia signed a $160.2 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement (#BLA04082) for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project. The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity of 15 years, a grace period of 7 years, and an interest rate of 3%. The proceeds from the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which was signed on September 24, 2004.   Then, on November 5, 2005, China Eximbank provided an additional $68.9 million to the Government of Indonesia for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project through an amendment to the PBC agreement that became effective on September 13, 2005 (captured in Project ID#61205). The additional PBC proceeds were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a supplemental commercial (EPC) contract worth $83.453 million between CRBC and the Ministry of Public Works of Indonesia, which was signed on July 9, 2008.   The purpose of the project was to construct the 5.4 kilometer long, 30 meter wide bridge linking the city of Suramadu with Madura Island (exact locational coordinates: 7°11′3″S 112°46′49″E). It is the first bridge to cross the Madura Strait. The cable-stayed portion has three spans with lengths 192 meters (630 ft), 434 meters (1,424 ft), and 192 meters (630 ft). The bridge has two lanes in each direction plus an emergency lane and a dedicated lane for motorcycles in each direction.   CRBC was the general (EPC) contractor responsible for implementation. However, China Harbor Engineering Co. Ltd. and a consortium of Indonesian companies, PT Adhi Karya and PT Waskita Karya, were also involved in implementation (most likely as subcontractors).   Construction began on November 19, 2005. The main span of Suramadu Bridge linking Surabaya in East Java mainland and Madura Island was connected successfully at midnight local time on Tuesday, March 31, 2009. The bridge was officially open to traffic on June 10, 2009. Within a week of the opening, it was discovered that nuts and bolts as well as maintenance lamps had been stolen and that there was evidence of vandalism of cables supporting the main span. As is often the case with public sector infrastructure facilities in Indonesia, there has been pressure to keep the tariffs for use of the bridge low. Tolls were initially set at Rp30,000 (USD $3 in 2009) for four-wheeled vehicles and Rp3,000 (USD $0.30) for two-wheelers. However, in early 2016, it was announced that President Jokowi favored a 50% cut in the tolls to help promote the competitiveness of industries on the Madura side of the bridge. On October 27, 2018, toll tariffs were abolished for all types of vehicles.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Suramadu Bridge Project or the Surabaya-Madura Bridge Project. The Chinese project title is 泗水－马都拉大桥 or 印尼泗水-马都拉大桥项目. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides $160.2 million preferential buyer's credit loan for Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge (linked to #61205)

# Description
In June 2004, China Exim Bank and the Government Indonesia signed a memorandum of understanding regarding a loan for the  Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project. Then, on November 5, 2004, China Eximbank and the Government of Indonesia signed a $160.2 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement (#BLA04082) for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project. The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity of 15 years, a grace period of 7 years, and an interest rate of 3%. The proceeds from the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which was signed on September 24, 2004.   Then, on November 5, 2005, China Eximbank provided an additional $68.9 million to the Government of Indonesia for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project through an amendment to the PBC agreement that became effective on September 13, 2005 (captured in Project ID#61205). The additional PBC proceeds were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a supplemental commercial (EPC) contract worth $83.453 million between CRBC and the Ministry of Public Works of Indonesia, which was signed on July 9, 2008.   The purpose of the project was to construct the 5.4 kilometer long, 30 meter wide bridge linking the city of Suramadu with Madura Island (exact locational coordinates: 7°11′3″S 112°46′49″E). It is the first bridge to cross the Madura Strait. The cable-stayed portion has three spans with lengths 192 meters (630 ft), 434 meters (1,424 ft), and 192 meters (630 ft). The bridge has two lanes in each direction plus an emergency lane and a dedicated lane for motorcycles in each direction.   CRBC was the general (EPC) contractor responsible for implementation. However, China Harbor Engineering Co. Ltd. and a consortium of Indonesian companies, PT Adhi Karya and PT Waskita Karya, were also involved in implementation (most likely as subcontractors).   Construction began on November 19, 2005. The main span of Suramadu Bridge linking Surabaya in East Java mainland and Madura Island was connected successfully at midnight local time on Tuesday, March 31, 2009. The bridge was officially open to traffic on June 10, 2009. Within a week of the opening, it was discovered that nuts and bolts as well as maintenance lamps had been stolen and that there was evidence of vandalism of cables supporting the main span. As is often the case with public sector infrastructure facilities in Indonesia, there has been pressure to keep the tariffs for use of the bridge low. Tolls were initially set at Rp30,000 (USD $3 in 2009) for four-wheeled vehicles and Rp3,000 (USD $0.30) for two-wheelers. However, in early 2016, it was announced that President Jokowi favored a 50% cut in the tolls to help promote the competitiveness of industries on the Madura side of the bridge. On October 27, 2018, toll tariffs were abolished for all types of vehicles.
justification: The project is a transportation infrastructure project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of 5.4 km bridge connecting Surabaya and Madura Island, general transportation infrastructure

title: China donates US$100,000 to Indonesia to fight against avian influenza outbreak
description: On February 10, 2004, the Chinese Embassy in Indonesia donated US$100000 to the Indonesian government to fight the avian influenza outbreak.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates US$100,000 to Indonesia to fight against avian influenza outbreak

# Description
On February 10, 2004, the Chinese Embassy in Indonesia donated US$100000 to the Indonesian government to fight the avian influenza outbreak.
justification: Project is a healthcare-related donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation for avian influenza outbreak response, healthcare sector focus

title: China gives grant of US$40,000 to Indonesia for Nabire earthquake victims (Linked to #34946)
description: In February 2004, Chinese Ambassador to Indonesia Lu Shumin handed over a 40,000 USD donation to Indonesia for earthquake victims in Nabire. The earthquake hit on February 6, 2004, and measured 6.9 on the Richter scale. This aid comes alongside a grant of US$10000 to the Indonesian Red Cross. (#34946))
combined_text:

EMERGENCY RESPONSE

justification: Humanitarian aid for earthquake victims with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Grant for earthquake victims, humanitarian focus

title: China donated $50,000 to Indonesia for earthquake relief in East Nusa Tenggara
description: On November 17, 2004, China donated $50,000 to Indonesia for earthquake relief in Alor in East Nusa Tenggara. Chinese ambassador to Indonesia Lu Shu Min handed over the donation to the Indonesian Coordinating Minister for People's Welfare Alwi Shihab, intended to be used for medicine, food, and materials to repair the physical damage done by the earthquake. The earthquake had a magnitude of 6.5 on the Richter Scale, jolted nine sub-districts in Alor District, East Nusa Tenggara Province, on 12 November, and was followed by 1,000 aftershocks.  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #24332.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

The earthquake had a magnitude of 6.5 on the Richter Scale, jolted nine sub-districts in Alor District, East Nusa Tenggara Province, on 12 November, and was followed by 1,000 aftershocks.  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #24332.
justification: Project is a humanitarian donation for earthquake relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation for medicine, food, and materials for earthquake relief in Indonesia

title: China donated 50 tons of earthquake relief materials to Indonesia worth 5M RMB
description: On December 31, 2004, Chinese Ambassador to Indonesia Lu Shumin attended the Chinese government donated relief materials to the Indonesian government on North Sumatra offshore earthquake tsunami disaster ceremony in the Indonesian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, delivered emergency relief supplies worth 5 million Chinese yuan donated by the Chinese government to Indonesia. This batch of materials including tents, thread blankets and foodstuffs arrived in Medan, Indonesia by chartered flight on December 30.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donated 50 tons of earthquake relief materials to Indonesia worth 5M RMB

# Description
On December 31, 2004, Chinese Ambassador to Indonesia Lu Shumin attended the Chinese government donated relief materials to the Indonesian government on North Sumatra offshore earthquake tsunami disaster ceremony in the Indonesian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, delivered emergency relief supplies worth 5 million Chinese yuan donated by the Chinese government to Indonesia. This batch of materials including tents, thread blankets and foodstuffs arrived in Medan, Indonesia by chartered flight on December 30.
justification: Project involves humanitarian aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Earthquake relief materials including tents, blankets, and foodstuffs, humanitarian focus

title: China sends 1st Search and Rescue Team to Indonesia as part of Tsunami Relief efforts
description: On December 31, 2004, the 35-person rescue team from China arrived in Medan. The team consists of members from China Earthquake Administration, doctors from The General Hospital of the Chinese People's Armed Police Forces, and soldiers from People's Liberation Army. The main tasks for the team included searching for and rescuing survivors, performing medical operations, as well as assessing and reporting the damage. After 11 days of operation in Banda Aceh, the team returned to China on January 11.
staff_comments: China contributed 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total, most of the individual project are captured in the linked resource #41811.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China sends 1st Search and Rescue Team to Indonesia as part of Tsunami Relief efforts

# Description
On December 31, 2004, the 35-person rescue team from China arrived in Medan. The team consists of members from China Earthquake Administration, doctors from The General Hospital of the Chinese People's Armed Police Forces, and soldiers from People's Liberation Army. The main tasks for the team included searching for and rescuing survivors, performing medical operations, as well as assessing and reporting the damage. After 11 days of operation in Banda Aceh, the team returned to China on January 11.
justification: Project is focused on emergency response and humanitarian aid without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Search and rescue operations, medical assistance, damage assessment in tsunami relief efforts

title: Overseas Chinese Affairs Office sends traditional Chinese physicians to Indonesia in December 2004
description: On December 23, 2004, a team of traditional Chinese physicians returned to Beijing after spending 21 days in Indonesia providing free medical consultations for around 5000 people. The team visited Medan, Kota Binjai, Siantar, Jakarta, Bandung, Surabaya and held 15 different consulting sessions. On average, each consulting session lasted for around half of a day, with more than 300 people receiving medical consultations. This project was financed by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Overseas Chinese Affairs Office sends traditional Chinese physicians to Indonesia in December 2004

# Description
On December 23, 2004, a team of traditional Chinese physicians returned to Beijing after spending 21 days in Indonesia providing free medical consultations for around 5000 people. The team visited Medan, Kota Binjai, Siantar, Jakarta, Bandung, Surabaya and held 15 different consulting sessions. On average, each consulting session lasted for around half of a day, with more than 300 people receiving medical consultations. This project was financed by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office.
justification: Project involves healthcare services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Traditional Chinese physicians providing free medical consultations, healthcare focus

title: China donated $203,021 to the World Health Organization for the re-establishment of the Health Information System in Indonesia after 2004 tsunami
description: In 2005, the Government of China donated $203,021 to the World Health Organization (WHO) to Indonesia for the re-establishment of the Health Information System in response to the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami. According to the WHO, the project aimed to "re-build the most essential components of the health information system and to re-establish the information network in Aceh and North Sumatra for disease surveillance, disease prevention and provision of health services and distribution of resources."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35252.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donated $203,021 to the World Health Organization for the re-establishment of the Health Information System in Indonesia after 2004 tsunami

# Description
In 2005, the Government of China donated $203,021 to the World Health Organization (WHO) to Indonesia for the re-establishment of the Health Information System in response to the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami. According to the WHO, the project aimed to "re-build the most essential components of the health information system and to re-establish the information network in Aceh and North Sumatra for disease surveillance, disease prevention and provision of health services and distribution of resources."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35252.
justification: Project focuses on health system recovery and humanitarian aid without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Health Information System re-establishment, disease surveillance, health services provision

title: China donates emergency supplies worth 10 million RMB to Indonesia after 2004 tsunami
description: On June 1, 2005, the Chinese Government handed over emergency supplies worth 10 million RMB to the Government of Indonesia for tsunami relief in Central Java. Emergency materials consisted of tents and blankets. Chinese government donated this material in response to the earthquake in Central Java, Yogyakarta. A total of 37.5 million yuan of disaster relief materials were provided to Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand, mainly including medicines, food and generators.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates emergency supplies worth 10 million RMB to Indonesia after 2004 tsunami

# Description
On June 1, 2005, the Chinese Government handed over emergency supplies worth 10 million RMB to the Government of Indonesia for tsunami relief in Central Java. Emergency materials consisted of tents and blankets. Chinese government donated this material in response to the earthquake in Central Java, Yogyakarta. A total of 37.5 million yuan of disaster relief materials were provided to Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand, mainly including medicines, food and generators.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and disaster relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Emergency supplies including tents, blankets, medicines, and food for tsunami relief
